title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős #611:** How do large cliques affect τ(G)?

**Q1:** If all maximal cliques have size ≥ cn, is τ = o(n)?
**Q2:** Estimate k_c(n) so that cliques ≥ k_c(n) force τ < (1-c)n.

**Known:** τ ≤ n - √(kn) when all cliques have size ≥ k.
**Special:** If cliques ≥ n + 3 - 2√n, then τ = 1 (Bollobás-Erdős).

title: AllCliquesLarge
content:
`AllCliquesLarge G k` means every maximal clique has at least k vertices.

This is the key constraint: we're asking how large cliques force small transversals.

For k = 2, this is trivially true (edges exist). For k = n, G must be complete.

title: AllCliquesLinear
content:
`AllCliquesLinear G c` means every clique has size ≥ cn for c ∈ (0,1).

This is a linear lower bound on clique size. For c = 1/2, every clique has at least n/2 vertices.

Such graphs are 'highly cliquey' — most vertices share cliques.

title: Question 1: Sublinear τ
content:
**Question 1:** If all cliques have size ≥ cn, is τ(G) = o_c(n)?

Formally: for every ε > 0, eventually τ(G) < εn.

**Answer:** YES! The Erdős-Gallai-Tuza bound gives τ ≤ (1-√c)n, which is strictly sublinear.

title: Question 2: Threshold k_c(n)
content:
**Question 2:** Find k_c(n) such that cliques ≥ k_c(n) ⟹ τ < (1-c)n.

**Threshold property:** k_c(n) is the minimum k achieving this.

**Known lower bound:** k_c(n) ≥ n^{c'/log log n} — very slow growth.

**Upper bound:** Not well understood!

title: Erdős-Gallai-Tuza Bound
content:
**Key Result:** If every clique has size ≥ k, then τ ≤ n - √(kn).

This is powerful: larger k ⟹ smaller τ. The √(kn) term grows with both k and n.

For k = 2 (trivial): τ ≤ n - √(2n), matching #610.

title: Linear Cliques → Sublinear τ
content:
**Consequence:** For k = cn, we get:

τ ≤ n - √(cn·n) = n - √c·n = (1-√c)n

For c = 1/4: τ ≤ n/2. For c = 1/2: τ ≤ (1-√0.5)n ≈ 0.29n.

This answers Question 1 affirmatively!

title: Threshold Lower Bound
content:
**Lower bound:** k_c(n) ≥ n^{c'/log log n} for some constant c'.

This grows VERY slowly — faster than any constant, but slower than n^ε for any ε > 0.

Example: For n = 10^6, log log n ≈ 2.56, so n^{1/2.56} ≈ n^{0.39}.

title: Bollobás-Erdős Threshold
content:
The critical threshold for τ = 1 is:

n + 3 - 2√n

For n = 100: threshold = 100 + 3 - 20 = 83.
For n = 10000: threshold = 10000 + 3 - 200 = 9803.

Almost all vertices must be in every clique!

title: τ = 1 Theorem
content:
**Bollobás-Erdős:** If all cliques have size ≥ n + 3 - 2√n, then τ(G) = 1.

This means a SINGLE vertex hits every maximal clique!

Intuitively: cliques are so large they must all overlap significantly.

title: Threshold Optimality
content:
The threshold n + 3 - 2√n is **optimal**.

For any ε > 0, there exist graphs where:
- All cliques have size ≥ n + 3 - 2√n - ε
- But τ ≥ 2 (no single vertex works)

The constant 3 is exact!

title: Complete Graph
content:
**Complete graph Kₙ:** τ = 1

There's one maximal clique (all n vertices). Any single vertex hits it.

This satisfies the Bollobás-Erdős condition: clique size n ≥ n + 3 - 2√n for n ≥ 9.

title: Complete Bipartite Graph
content:
**K_{n/2,n/2}:** Cliques have size 2, so τ = n/2.

Every edge is a maximal clique. Need one endpoint from each edge.

This is the worst case for clique size 2.

title: Random Graph Lower Bound
content:
Random graphs show the lower bound on k_c(n) is necessary.

There exist graphs with:
- All cliques have size ≈ n^{c/log log n}
- But τ ≈ (1-c)n

So k_c(n) must grow at least this fast.

title: Relationship to #610
content:
**#611 refines #610** by adding clique size constraints.

#610 asks about τ in general.
#611 asks: if we KNOW cliques are large, can we do better?

Answer: YES — the bound τ ≤ n - √(kn) improves with k.

title: Main Status
content:
**Erdős Problem #611: PARTIALLY RESOLVED**

**Q1:** ANSWERED — τ ≤ (1-√c)n for linear cliques.

**Q2:** OPEN — k_c(n) ≥ n^{c'/log log n} is known, but tight bounds remain elusive.

**Special case:** The τ = 1 threshold n + 3 - 2√n is exactly known (Bollobás-Erdős).
